awd_titl_txt: RUI:  CSBR:  Natural History Collections:  Modernization and Consolidation of the Natural History Collections at MSU into the Xeric Ecosystem Research Center (XERC)
awd_abstract_narration:
Maintaining an accessible record of biodiversity is of great importance, especially given current ecological threats such as a rapidly changing climate, invasive species, habitat destruction, and urbanization.  This record is particularly important for ecosystems whose species are underrepresented in biological research collections, and therefore less understood.  Among such ecosystems within the continental United States are the Central Plains and the Southwestern Deserts.  The collections at Midwestern State University (MSU) in Wichita Falls, Texas holds a robust sample of specimens from the Rolling Plains ecosystem and the Chihuahuan Desert of the Trans-Pecos ecoregion. These collections are currently maintained as three taxonomically separated entities. By consolidating the vertebrate, terrestrial invertebrate, and plant collections at MSU into the Xeric Ecosystem Research Center (XERC), modernizing the infrastructure, and digitizing specimen data, the collection will become much more useful and accessible to scientists and members of the public.  XERC will also, through outreach programs and special museum exhibits, increase the understanding and appreciation of xeric ecosystem biodiversity among young learners and highlight the historical significance of plants and animals to the Native Americans who once occupied these ecosystems.  

The Xeric Ecosystem Research Center will consolodate all specimens currently in natural history collections at Midwestern State University.  Many of these specimen records were historically maintained as paper documents that will now be digitized by student assistants and citizen scientists, validated by curators, and made available to the public through iDigBio (http://www.idigbio.org). Herbarium specimens will be photographed and digitized to create a virtual herbarium that will also be publicly accessible.  Specimen cabinets will be repaired and upgraded to industry standards, the capacity to maintain molecular data will be enhanced with upgraded environmental storage, and an integrated pest management plan will be instituted.  Midwestern State will actively promote XERC to the broader scientific community and encourage broad use of the specimens and data contained therein. To enhance the educational and cultural value of XERC, an ADA accessible website and associated educational materials aimed at young learners (K-5) will be produced and made widely available. XERC will partner with the Wichita Falls Museum of Art (WFMA) to produce two public exhibits that highlights biodiversity of the Trans-Pecos ecoregion of Texas and the cultural significance of plants and animals of the Central Plains to early Native Americans. Through these efforts, the Xeric Ecosystem Research Center will serve as a hub for research, a record of biodiversity, and a repository for important biological materials from xeric ecosystems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The primary objective of this project consolidated Midwestern State University's (MSU) large and diverse natural history collections into one cohesive research center with modern facilities and a digital database to improve access and effectiveness of this resource for MSU researchers, their students, and the greater scientific community. This was made possible with updated infrastructure, using student curatorial assistants to  digitize and georeference, when possible, the collection.

The Xeric Ecosystem Research Center (XERC),  houses two regional collections; one focusing upon the prairie ecosystem of North Texas and Western Oklahoma, and the other representing the Trans-Pecos region of the Chihuahuan Desert where MSU manages the Dalquest Desert Research Station (DDRS).

MSU currently houses one of the largest (3rd) collection of mammal specimens in the State of Texas. This is the cornerstone of a collection that includes 23,000+ vertebrates, 100,000+ arthropods, and 4000 plants. Within the arthropod collection, there are over 670 species of spiders representing 56 families. This is on par with the largest and most complete collections of spiders in Texas.

Improvements made the existing collection available to visiting researchers and remote users through a digitized collection.  The biodiversity of xeric ecoregions are of global interest. Even though the Rolling Plains and GreatPlains ecoregions of Texas are diverse, they are in constant peril due to a changing climate, invasivespecies, fire suppression, conversion to cropland, oil and gas extraction, and overgrazing. Documenting biodiversity in this ecoregion is therefore a high priority. XERC will fulfill this need in concert with DDRS to document the biodiversity of the Trans-Pecos and Great/Rolling Plains ecoregions of Texas.

We modernized storage by purchasing raised specimen cases and updated the pest management systems. We purchased two ultra-cold freezers for tissue storage. Additionally, we developed a space for an accesion room where we could process and photograph incoming specimens to further prevent contamination to our overall collection.These improvements provide better long-term storage and ensure their availabilty for researchers and educational projects.

Our displays in the main biology building and talks at the art museum have increased public undersatanding of the importance of this collection and has hopefully inspired future STEM students.
